articles.title: Trump Backs Off San Francisco Federal Deployment After Mayor’s Appeal
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: President Donald Trump reversed plans to deploy federal agents, including U.S. Customs and Border Protection personnel, into San Francisco after speaking with Mayor Daniel Lurie, who reported progress in reducing city crime. The original deployment was met with protests, including demonstrators singing hymns and carrying signs opposing 'ICE or troops in the Bay.' Local officials, including Mayor Lurie and Governor Gavin Newsom, condemned the move, calling it an attempt to provoke chaos and violence. While it remains unclear whether the cancellation specifically applies to CBP or National Guard forces, the incident reflects broader national debates over federal militarization, immigration enforcement, and local governance autonomy. The event took place at Coast Guard Island in Alameda, a long-standing federal base, and underscores tensions between federal policy and community-led crime reduction strategies.
keyTakeAways: President Donald Trump announced he was backing off a planned surge of federal agents into San Francisco after speaking with Mayor Daniel Lurie.
The decision followed reports that over 100 U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) agents were to arrive at Coast Guard Island in Alameda to track down undocumented immigrants.
Protesters gathered at the base, carrying signs such as 'Protect our neighbors' and 'No ICE or troops in the Bay,' expressing opposition to federal immigration enforcement.
Police used a flash-bang grenade to clear demonstrators from the base entrance as CBP vehicles arrived.
Mayor Daniel Lurie stated that Trump called off the deployment after receiving a phone call, and Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem reaffirmed this direction.
City officials, including Governor Gavin Newsom, criticized the move as intended to provoke chaos and violence, emphasizing that crime rates in San Francisco are at record lows.
The deployment was seen as part of a broader pattern of Trump’s calls for National Guard or militarized immigration enforcement in cities like Washington, D.C., Memphis, Chicago, and Portland.
There is uncertainty about whether the cancellation applies to National Guard deployment or specifically CBP immigration enforcement.
Coast Guard Island is a federal site used for operations and not open to the public, and the base has a long history dating back to 1926.

articles.title: U.S. Ships Millions of Tons of Discarded Electronics to Southeast Asia, Report Finds
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: A new report by the Seattle-based Basel Action Network (BAN) reveals a growing and largely unregulated flow of discarded electronics from the United States to developing nations in Southeast Asia, including Malaysia, Indonesia, Thailand, the Philippines, and the UAE. Despite international bans under the Basel Convention and national laws, U.S. companies such as Attan Recycling, CEWS, Creative Metals Group, and others are shipping over 10,000 containers of e-waste valued at more than $1 billion between January 2023 and February 2025. Much of this waste is falsely labeled under trade codes like 'commodity materials' to evade detection, and it is often processed in informal scrapyards where workers face exposure to toxic fumes containing lead, cadmium, and mercury. The article highlights that eight of the 10 companies involved hold R2V3 certifications, raising questions about the integrity of environmental standards. Malaysia, in particular, has become a major recipient of this illegal trade, with authorities seizing significant quantities, such as 238 tons in Thailand and $118 million in Malaysia. Experts argue this constitutes 'waste colonialism,' where developed nations transfer hazardous waste to poorer countries, overwhelming local systems and endangering public health and the environment.
keyTakeAways: U.S. companies are exporting millions of tons of discarded electronics to developing countries in Southeast Asia, where they are processed under unsafe and unregulated conditions.

The report identifies 10 U.S. companies, including Attan Recycling, Corporate eWaste Solutions (CEWS), Creative Metals Group, EDM, First America Metal Corp., GEM Iron and Metal Inc., Greenland Resource, IQA Metals, PPM Recycling, and Semsotai, involved in the export of electronic waste.

Much of the e-waste is shipped under false trade classifications such as 'commodity materials' to evade detection under the Basel Convention, which bans hazardous waste trade from non-signatory nations like the U.S.
The e-waste shipments are valued at over $1 billion between January 2023 and February 2025, with industry-wide trade potentially reaching $200 million per month.
Countries such as Malaysia, Indonesia, Thailand, the Philippines, and the UAE have become major destinations for this illegal trade, despite national and international bans.
Workers in informal scrapyards often handle waste manually without protection, releasing toxic fumes containing lead, cadmium, and mercury.
Eight of the 10 companies hold R2V3 certifications, raising questions about the effectiveness and integrity of these environmental standards.
The Basel Convention, an international treaty, bans hazardous waste trade from non-signatory nations, but the U.S. remains the only major industrialized nation that has not ratified it.
Malaysia, a Basel Convention signatory, is particularly burdened by the influx of U.S. e-waste, with many of the facilities operating illegally and lacking environmental safeguards.

Authorities in Thailand and Malaysia have conducted raids and seizures, including 238 tons in Thailand and $118 million worth of waste in Malaysia, highlighting active efforts to curb illegal imports.

articles.title: Trump Suggests He’s Entitled to Compensation from Federal Government Over Past Investigations
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: President Donald Trump has filed two administrative claims with the Justice Department seeking $230 million in damages, citing politically motivated investigations into his conduct, including the 2022 FBI search of his Mar-a-Lago property and the Trump-Russia investigation. Under the Federal Tort Claims Act, such claims must first go through an administrative review, with the Justice Department having six months to respond. Trump has not yet filed a lawsuit, despite the deadline passing. A major ethical concern arises because top Justice Department officials—such as Deputy Attorney General Todd Blanche and Associate Attorney General Stanley Woodward—who previously defended Trump or his allies, are now involved in approving any potential settlement. The possibility of Trump receiving taxpayer-funded compensation from the very agency he leads has sparked significant controversy, with Democrats launching an investigation into what they describe as a constitutional shakedown. The situation highlights deep conflicts of interest, potential misuse of power, and the integrity of federal oversight.

articles.title: Peru Declares State of Emergency Amid Rising Crime and Public Skepticism
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Peru’s newly elected President José Jerí declared a state of emergency in October 2025, following the removal of former President Dina Boluarte, who was criticized for failing to control rising crime. The decree suspended constitutional rights, banned certain activities like two adults riding motorcycles, and allowed power cuts in prisons. However, residents like Manuel Timoteo have voiced skepticism, arguing that past emergency measures under Boluarte were ineffective and that crime, including homicides and extortion, has worsened over recent years. The article highlights deep public distrust in emergency responses and the ongoing struggle to maintain public safety in Lima.
keyTakeAways: Peru's capital, Lima, saw increased military and police presence under new President José Jerí, who declared a state of emergency to combat rising crime.
The state of emergency suspended constitutional rights such as freedom of assembly and protest, banned two adults riding on motorcycles, and allowed power cuts in prison cells except for lighting.
The decree was declared a week after a violent protest resulted in one death and a severe injury, which contributed to public unrest and political instability.
The public, including residents like Manuel Timoteo, expressed skepticism, arguing that previous states of emergency under Dina Boluarte failed to reduce crime and extortion.

Peru has experienced a significant rise in crime: homicides increased from 676 in 2017 to 2,082 in 2024, and extortion complaints surged from 2,305 in 2020 to 21,746 in 2024, primarily affecting the working class.
Previous emergency measures under Dina Boluarte were criticized for being ineffective, especially in protecting public transport workers and small businesses from criminal extortion.
José Jerí assumed office after lawmakers removed Dina Boluarte, partly due to her inability to control crime, indicating a political shift in response to public safety failures.

articles.title: Two Buses Crash on Ugandan Highway, Killing at Least 46 in One of the Worst Accidents in Years
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: A deadly bus crash occurred on the highway to Gulu in western Uganda on Wednesday, killing at least 46 people after two buses collided head-on during an overtaking maneuver near Kiryandongo. Police initially reported 63 deaths but revised the figure to 46 after realizing some individuals found unconscious were still alive. The incident is one of the worst road accidents in Uganda in recent years and highlights a persistent problem of reckless driving, especially careless overtaking, which accounted for 44.5% of crashes in 2024. Road safety campaigners like Joseph Beyanga and Red Cross spokesperson Irene Nakasiita have criticized the lack of enforcement, poor road infrastructure, and nighttime driving risks. Uganda’s road fatality numbers have risen significantly from 4,534 in 2022 to 5,144 in 2024, signaling a growing emergency in road safety that is shared across East Africa, including in Kenya.

articles.title: American chess grandmaster Daniel Naroditsky dies at 29
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The International Chess Federation (FIDE) is considering disciplinary action against Russian grandmaster Vladimir Kramnik for making repeated, unsubstantiated cheating allegations against American grandmaster Daniel Naroditsky over the year leading up to Naroditsky’s death. Naroditsky, who died at age 29, had consistently denied the claims, accusing Kramnik of harassment and attempts to ruin his life. FIDE, under President Arkady Dvorkovich, has formally referred Kramnik’s public statements to its Ethics and Disciplinary Commission, citing concerns about bullying and harm to players' well-being. The chess community, including Magnus Carlsen and Hikaru Nakamura, has condemned Kramnik’s conduct as toxic and damaging. The article highlights a broader issue of public accusations and emotional abuse in online chess, especially in speed formats where emotional tolls are high. In response, FIDE will establish a memorial prize in Naroditsky’s name to honor his contributions to blitz and bullet chess.

Kramnik previously faced criticism for spreading baseless accusations, including against David Navara, leading to mental health crises in other players.

articles.title: San Francisco Giants Hire College Coach Tony Vitello as First-Time Manager
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The San Francisco Giants have made a bold move by hiring Tony Vitello, a college baseball coach with no prior professional experience, as their new manager. Vitello, who led the University of Tennessee to a College World Series title in 2024 and multiple NCAA appearances, is being brought in to bring innovation, player development focus, and a strong competitive culture to the team after a four-year playoff drought. The hiring reflects a strategic shift, inspired by historical precedents such as Jimmy Johnson and the Dallas Cowboys, and demonstrates the Giants' desire for stability and a fresh voice in a period of leadership transition. Despite past suspensions for on-field conduct and controversies, Vitello's dedication to player development and community service has made him a compelling choice. His background at Tennessee, including a strong draft pipeline and stadium renovations, further strengthens his appeal as a long-term leader.
keyTakeAways: Tony Vitello, a college baseball coach with no prior professional experience, was hired by the San Francisco Giants as their new manager, marking a bold move to bring a fresh, innovative approach to the team.

Vitello has led the University of Tennessee to significant success, including a College World Series title in 2024, six regional appearances, five super regional berths, and three College World Series trips.

Vitello’s coaching philosophy emphasizes competitiveness, player development, and on-field passion, aligning with the Giants' values and mission.

Despite being suspended twice during his college coaching tenure for on-field conduct, Vitello has demonstrated a commitment to community and charity, reinforcing his image as a passionate and socially conscious leader.

The move mirrors a precedent seen in other sports, such as the NFL’s Dallas Cowboys hiring Jimmy Johnson, showing a strategic trend of professional teams turning to college coaches for innovative leadership.

articles.title: Illinois Sheriff’s Deputy Charged with Murder of Sonya Massey in Home Confrontation
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The murder trial of former Sangamon County Sheriff’s Deputy Sean Grayson, accused of killing Sonya Massey in her Springfield home on July 6, 2024, centers on allegations that Grayson violated police training and principles by shooting a woman who had called 911 for a suspected prowler. The prosecution argues that Massey posed no threat, and body camera footage shows her calmly interacting with Grayson, including a statement of 'I rebuke you in the name of Jesus,' which Grayson misinterpreted as a threat. Grayson’s use of deadly force—firing three shots while she was unarmed—led to her death. The case has sparked public debate over racial bias in policing, particularly involving Black women, and prompted changes in Illinois law requiring greater background transparency for law enforcement recruits. The defense claims the use of force was reasonable, while the prosecution emphasizes a failure of training and de-escalation principles. Additionally, inconsistencies in evidence collection—such as the pot of hot water being left untouched for weeks—raise questions about accountability and protocol in law enforcement operations.
keyTakeAways: Sean Grayson, a former Sangamon County Sheriff’s deputy, is on trial for three counts of first-degree murder for shooting Sonya Massey in her Springfield home on July 6, 2024.
The prosecution argues that Grayson violated police training and principles by shooting Massey, who had called 911 about a suspected prowler and posed no threat.
The body camera video revealed that Grayson and Massey were joking, and that Massey only said 'I rebuke you in the name of Jesus' before being shot.
Grayson claimed he believed Massey intended to kill him when she made that statement, leading to his use of force.
The pot of hot water was left untouched in the home for weeks after the shooting, raising questions about whether it was properly collected and documented.

Farley, another deputy, testified that he drew his weapon due to Grayson’s actions and later retracted his initial report to clarify that it was Grayson’s response, not the pot, that caused his concern.
The case has prompted changes in Illinois law requiring fuller background disclosure for law enforcement candidates.
Donna Massey, Sonya’s mother, was seen in tears during the trial, highlighting the emotional impact on the family and public.

articles.title: Wolff Sues Trumps Over Epstein-Related Statements, Alleges Threats of $1 Billion Damages
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Author Michael Wolff has filed a lawsuit against First Lady Melania Trump and President Donald Trump, alleging that they threatened to sue him for over $1 billion in damages if he retracted statements he made about their ties to Jeffrey Epstein. Wolff claims the threats are part of a broader strategy to intimidate critics, silence free speech, and extract financial compensation. The lawsuit includes specific claims about Melania Trump's involvement in Epstein’s social circle and Donald Trump’s sexual conduct with other women, including a claim that he first slept with Melania on Epstein’s private jet. Wolff asserts that some of his statements were protected opinion and not defamatory, and that the case should include inquiry into the Trumps’ decade-long pursuit of models. In response, Melania Trump’s lawyer called the statements 'malicious and defamatory' and emphasized her commitment to fighting false narratives. The case has sparked national debate over political accountability, free speech, and the use of legal threats to suppress dissent.

Wolff asserts that his statements—made in articles and social media posts—were truthful, including claims that Melania Trump was 'very involved' in Epstein’s social circle and that Donald Trump had sexual relationships with other women and first slept with Melania Trump on Epstein’s private jet.
The lawsuit includes a request to place the Trumps under oath to answer questions about their relationship with Epstein and the broader pattern of pursuing models over a decade.

Wolff denies making any claims that Melania Trump was involved in Epstein’s crimes, and clarifies that the statements were opinions or incomplete phrases, with some being protected speech.
The case has sparked national debate about free speech, political accountability, and the use of legal threats to suppress criticism of public figures.

articles.title: Coast Guard Deploys CBP Agents in San Francisco Bay Area Amid Political and Legal Pushback
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The U.S. Coast Guard has established a base in Alameda, California, to support over 100 U.S. Customs and Border Protection agents in their efforts to detect and interdict illegal immigration and criminal activity. The move is immediately condemned by San Francisco Mayor Daniel Lurie and California Governor Gavin Newsom, who claim it is designed to provoke violent protests and justify the deployment of National Guard troops. Local leaders, including Oakland Mayor Barbara Lee and California Attorney General Rob Bonta, are preparing legal and public resistance, asserting that public safety should be addressed through local, not federal, solutions. President Donald Trump has repeatedly advocated for National Guard deployment in San Francisco, citing concerns over crime, though no such deployment has taken place as of the article’s publication. The situation reflects a broader national debate over immigration enforcement, federal authority, and the role of militarization in civilian policing.

The move is criticized as a provocation designed to incite violent protests, with local officials arguing that aggressive enforcement tactics are intended to create chaos and justify military intervention.

President Donald Trump has previously advocated for deploying National Guard troops in cities like Los Angeles, Chicago, and Portland, and has reiterated plans for San Francisco, though no deployment has occurred as of the article's publication.

Local officials, including Mayor Lurie, Oakland Mayor Barbara Lee, and California Attorney General Rob Bonta, have vowed legal and public resistance to any federal military deployment, asserting that public safety should be addressed through local solutions.
The Coast Guard and Homeland Security emphasize their focus on targeting 'the worst of the worst' criminal aliens, including violent offenders, rather than broad immigration enforcement.

articles.title: New York Mayoral Debate: Mamdani, Cuomo, and Sliwa Clash Over Experience, Politics, and National Issues
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: In a contentious final debate of New York City’s mayoral race, frontrunner Zohran Mamdani faced criticism over his thin resume and progressive stances, while challenging rivals Curtis Sliwa and former Governor Andrew Cuomo on their qualifications and past controversies. Mamdani, a democratic socialist, emphasized affordability and community-focused policies, and notably invited former accuser Charlotte Bennett to attend, aiming to humanize the sexual harassment allegations against Cuomo. Cuomo, running as an independent, leveraged his experience to counter Mamdani’s lack of credentials and defended himself against allegations of sexual misconduct, which prompted the debate’s central conflict. The candidates also addressed national issues, including President Donald Trump’s threats to take over the city, federal immigration enforcement on Canal Street, and police reform. Sliwa criticized both candidates for personal attacks and urged moderation, while both Mamdani and Cuomo opposed federal interventions in city affairs, citing concerns over accountability and civil liberties. The debate underscored the intersection of local politics with national issues, including immigration, policing, and leadership under political pressure.

Former Governor Andrew Cuomo, running as an independent, highlighted his political experience and downplayed Mamdani’s credentials, while defending his own record amid allegations.

articles.title: mRNA Vaccines May Improve Survival in Cancer Patients Receiving Immunotherapy
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: A study by researchers at MD Anderson Cancer Center and the University of Florida found that patients with advanced lung or skin cancer who received a Pfizer or Moderna mRNA vaccine within 100 days of starting immunotherapy treatment lived substantially longer. The research suggests that the mRNA molecule in these vaccines activates immune cells throughout the body, making tumors more vulnerable to immune therapy. The effect was not seen with non-mRNA vaccines like flu shots, and the findings support future clinical trials to combine existing mRNA vaccines with checkpoint inhibitors. Despite skepticism from Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and a $500 million cut in funding for mRNA technology, this research offers a promising new application of mRNA vaccines beyond pandemic response, potentially transforming cancer treatment.
keyTakeAways: mRNA vaccines, such as those used for COVID-19, may enhance the effectiveness of cancer immunotherapy by boosting immune system activity against tumors.
Patients with advanced lung or skin cancer who received a Pfizer or Moderna mRNA vaccine within 100 days of starting checkpoint inhibitor therapy had substantially longer survival.
The effect is due to the mRNA molecule activating immune cells throughout the body, making previously immune-resistant tumors more vulnerable to treatment.
Non-mRNA vaccines, like flu shots, did not show the same benefit, highlighting the specific role of mRNA technology.
This finding supports further study into combining existing mRNA vaccines with cancer treatments, potentially leading to new off-the-shelf therapies.
Researchers from MD Anderson Cancer Center and the University of Florida conducted the study analyzing nearly 1,000 patients with advanced lung or melanoma cancer.

articles.title: Former British Paratrooper Acquitted in Bloody Sunday Murder Case
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: A former British paratrooper known only as 'Soldier F' has been acquitted of murder and attempted murder charges related to the 1972 Bloody Sunday massacre in Londonderry, Northern Ireland, where 13 civilians were killed and 15 wounded. The trial, which lasted five weeks and involved no jury, centered on whether Soldier F opened fire with intent to kill. The judge, Patrick Lynch, ruled that the prosecution's sole evidence—hearsay statements from two other veterans, one deceased and one who refused to testify—was unverifiable and insufficient to meet legal standards. The verdict has been criticized by victims’ families as a failure of the British state to properly investigate and hold accountable those responsible, especially given decades-long claims of a cover-up. The case highlights the challenges of achieving justice in historical trauma, where memories fade and evidence is anecdotal. It also reflects broader tensions over institutional accountability, military conduct, and the legacy of 'The Troubles' in Northern Ireland and beyond.
keyTakeAways: Soldier F, a former British paratrooper, was found not guilty of murder and attempted murder charges related to the 1972 Bloody Sunday massacre in Derry.
The prosecution relied solely on hearsay statements from two other veterans, one of whom is deceased and the other who refused to testify, which the judge deemed unverifiable and unreliable.
Judge Patrick Lynch ruled that the evidence failed to meet the legal standard for conviction, citing delays and lack of corroboration, especially given the passage of time and fading memories.

The verdict has been criticized by victims’ families as a failure of the British state to deliver justice, especially given the long-standing claim that soldiers fired in self-defense and the subsequent cover-up.

The case reflects the broader challenges of pursuing justice decades after traumatic events, particularly when evidence is hearsay, memories are fragmented, and institutional accountability is delayed.

The British government, including current Prime Minister Keir Starmer, acknowledged the complexity of the Troubles' legacy and emphasized a need for fair, balanced approaches to historical accountability and closure.

This verdict is significant not only for the individual case but also for the ongoing dialogue about military accountability, institutional cover-ups, and the moral responsibility of states during conflicts.

articles.title: North Korea Tests New Hypersonic Missile System Ahead of APEC Summit
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: North Korea conducted ballistic missile tests involving new hypersonic systems, claiming successful strikes on land targets in its northern region. These tests, reported by the state media KCNA, come amid a broader military buildup under leader Kim Jong Un, who has emphasized strengthening nuclear deterrence. The launches occurred just before a major international gathering of world leaders, including U.S. President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping, at the APEC meeting, heightening regional tensions. Kim’s military officials, such as Pak Jong Chon, have praised the new weapons as 'cutting-edge,' signaling a commitment to advancing strategic capabilities. The tests follow a pattern of increasing missile development after the collapse of nuclear diplomacy in 2019, and occur amid South Korea’s new leadership under President Lee Jae Myung, who has advocated for peace, while North Korea continues to reject diplomatic overtures. The U.S. and South Korea have responded by reaffirming their commitment to regional stability and calling on North Korea to halt its unlawful missile activities.
keyTakeAways: North Korea conducted ballistic missile tests involving hypersonic projectiles, claiming they accurately hit a land target and are part of a new strategic war deterrent.
The missile tests occurred shortly before the APEC summit, where U.S. President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping are expected to meet, increasing regional tensions.
The tests are part of a broader effort by North Korea to counter South Korean and U.S. missile defenses, particularly through hypersonic glide vehicles designed to evade detection.
Kim Jong Un’s military officials, including Pak Jong Chon, have publicly praised the new systems, signaling a commitment to strengthening nuclear capabilities.
North Korea has not responded to South Korea’s new leadership under President Lee Jae Myung, which has sought to promote peace on the Korean Peninsula.
The developments follow a decline in diplomatic engagement after the failure of U.S.-North Korea nuclear diplomacy in 2019, with Kim accelerating weapons development.

articles.title: Taylor Swift, Kenny Loggins, and Others Nominated for 2026 Songwriters Hall of Fame
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The Songwriters Hall of Fame has announced its 2026 class of nominees, featuring a diverse and historically significant mix of pop, rock, hip-hop, country, and R&B songwriters. The list includes major figures like Taylor Swift, Kenny Loggins, LL Cool J, and Pink, as well as legends such as Gene Simmons and Paul Stanley of Kiss, and key songwriters from bands like The Go-Go’s, The Guess Who, and America. The inclusion of artists like Walter Afanasieff and returning nominees like Randy Bachman and Bob McDill underscores both the enduring legacy and evolving nature of popular music. The announcement comes shortly after the death of Ace Frehley, a founding member of Kiss, adding emotional weight to the recognition of the band’s songwriting and cultural impact. Voting closes on December 4, 2025, with inductees to be announced in early 2026.
keyTakeAways: The 2026 Songwriters Hall of Fame class includes a diverse group of performers and songwriters across pop, hip-hop, folk, rock, R&B, and country genres.
Notable nominees include Taylor Swift, Kenny Loggins, LL Cool J, Pink, Sarah McLachlan, David Byrne, Gene Simmons, Paul Stanley, and Richard Carpenter.
The list features both first-time nominees and returning artists such as Walter Afanasieff, Randy Bachman, Burton Cummings, and Bob McDill.
The Songwriters Hall of Fame was established in 1969 to honor influential creators of popular music, with eligibility based on 20 years after the first commercial release of a song.
The 2025 class included George Clinton, The Doobie Brothers, Ashley Gorley, Rodney 'Darkchild' Jerkins, and The Beach Boys’ Mike Love and Tony Macaulay.
The 2026 inductees will be announced in early 2026, following a voting period ending on December 4, 2025.
The inclusion of Ace Frehley’s death shortly before the announcement highlights the emotional and cultural significance of the Hall's recognition of music legends.

articles.title: Monks and Nuns Harvest Olives at Mount of Olives Amid Ceasefire in Israel-Hamas War
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: In the midst of a two-year Israel-Hamas war that devastated the Holy Land, olive harvesting at the Mount of Olives and Gethsemane has resumed in 2025 following a ceasefire, symbolizing fragile peace and spiritual resilience. Monks and nuns, including Franciscan and Benedictine religious figures, conduct the harvest not for profit but as a sacred act of prayer, reverence, and spiritual reflection. The olive trees, historically tied to biblical events such as Jesus’ final night in Gethsemane, now represent both natural and religious continuity. Though the harvest is hampered by drought and wind damage, the act of pressing olives is interpreted as a metaphor for divine grace and human sacrifice. The presence of multiple religious communities — including Islamic sites like Al-Aqsa Mosque and the Temple Mount — underscores the shared spiritual landscape of Jerusalem. This year’s harvest serves as a powerful symbol of peace, echoing the biblical story of the dove returning to Noah’s Ark, and illustrates how faith and nature coexist in times of conflict.
keyTakeAways: Olive harvesting at the Mount of Olives and Gethsemane is a spiritual and symbolic act, not a commercial enterprise, for Christian monastic communities.
The olive harvest is tied to religious significance, with references to Jesus' final night before crucifixion and the biblical story of the dove symbolizing peace.
Despite the ongoing Israel-Hamas conflict and environmental challenges like drought and wind damage, a ceasefire agreement in 2025 has allowed a fragile return to normalcy, including the harvest.
The act of pressing olives is seen as a metaphor for human suffering, divine grace, and spiritual discipline — echoing the idea that people are 'picked' by God, just as olives are gathered.
Olive oil is used in sacraments such as anointing the sick and blessing of new altars, linking the harvest directly to Christian liturgical practices.

Title: Analysis: America’s 51st state? US pressure comes to bear on Israel

A succession of high-ranking US officials have found themselves in Israel in recent days – first special envoy  Steve Witkoff and presidential adviser Jared Kushner  on Monday, then Vice President  JD Vance  on Tuesday, and Secretary of State  Marco Rubio  on Thursday.

Their focus has been clear – to stop the US-backed  Gaza ceasefire deal  from collapsing. And that essentially means ensuring that the Israeli government of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu does not back out of the agreement, which ended two years of war earlier this month.

The presence of the US officials in Israel has been described as “babysitting” – designed to twist the arm of a far-right government itching to find any excuse to relaunch the war, which killed more than 68,000 Palestinians.

And so far, the administration of US President Donald Trump appears to have largely succeeded, highlighting what some analysts deem to be Israeli subservience to the US, and an acknowledgment that when Washington orders Israel to do something, the latter will ultimately agree.

“Of course, Israel is a client state of the US,” Alon Pinkas, a former Israeli ambassador and consul general in New York, told Al Jazeera. Pinkas referred to the billions of dollars Israel receives from the US in aid, the dozens of times Washington uses its veto to protect Israel from criticism or sanction at the United Nations, and its military protection of Israel.

Now the Trump administration is leveraging that support and doing what is a rare occurrence when it comes to relations between the two countries: forcing Israel to act according to the US’s wishes, and making public Washington’s pressure on Israel.

Some of that has come from Trump himself – in an interview published by Time Magazine on Thursday, the US president said that he had stopped Netanyahu from continuing the Gaza war. “You know, I stopped him, because he would have just kept going,” Trump said. “It could have gone on for years.”

Trump also made it clear in the same interview that Israel would lose “all support” from the US if it proceeded with the annexation of the occupied West Bank, which its parliament or Knesset preliminarily approved on Wednesday. Vance also  voiced his opposition  to an Israeli parliamentary vote on annexation, calling it “very stupid”.

Netanyahu understood the message, and his office called the vote a “political provocation” – even as members of his own government voted in favour, and even though he himself has previously backed annexation.

The US has always been the stronger party in the relationship with Israel. It is the global superpower, while Israel is an ally with a traditionally large constituency of support within the US.

But US governments, for whatever reason, have often tried to avoid any direct confrontation with Israel. Former US President Joe Biden adopted a “bear hug” policy towards Israel during the first three months of the war on Gaza, arguing that the Israelis needed to be publicly backed in order to convince them to avoid going too far in their destruction of the Palestinian enclave.

That did not work, with Netanyahu repeatedly ignoring attempts to get him to agree to a ceasefire. Instead, it was Trump, who is incredibly popular in Israel for the support he gave the country in his first term, who has taken the relatively more confrontational route with Israel since his return to the presidency. So far, it appears to be working.

“Benjamin Netanyahu has been put on notice,” Yossi Mekelberg, a senior consulting fellow at Chatham House, told Al Jazeera. “The US team can say all these different things –  as they are doing –  but it’s pretty obvious what their agenda is.

“Look at the 60 Minutes interview [US presidential adviser Jared] Kushner and [US special envoy Steve] Witkoff gave where they spoke of betrayal and a loss of control. To my mind, this contradicts all the shows of friendliness we’re seeing in the Israeli press. This is the Trump administration coming over and saying quite clearly: ‘You do as you’re told.'”

Mekelberg was referring to an interview aired by CBS News last week, in which Witkoff described both himself and Kushner as feeling “a little bit betrayed” by Israel’s decision to  strike  at the Hamas negotiating team in Doha, Qatar in September. Continuing, Kushner emphasised how Trump, his father-in-law, had felt the Israelis “were getting a little bit out of control in what they were doing, and that it was time to be very strong and stop them from doing things that he felt were not in their long-term interests”.

That may go to the root of explaining how Trump, despite his clear support for Israel and his past disparagement of the Palestinians, has been so vocal in criticising Israeli actions. The framing from his administration is that Trump’s restraint of Israel is in the latter’s benefit, highlighting the primacy of the US in the relationship, while also emphasising the bond between the US and Israel.

“The relationship between the US and Israel is a central part of both countries’ policies,” said Mitchell Barak, a former aide to Netanyahu. “It’s built on a shared sense of Judeo-Christian values, but Israel is also a valuable strategic partner to the US; it’s also vital in its regional policy as well as providing advances in innovation.”

“And what’s more – as we’re seeing from both US business, as well as the Trump family business, who are heavily invested in the region – stability and peace are profitable for all.”

“It’s true that Israel’s lost some of its independence in this, but there’s nothing new in that,” Barak added. “I think that’s what we’re seeing right now in the way the US is managing the ceasefire. It’s a combination of carrot and stick and right now, with Vance and the others over, is a reminder of the stick.”

And as for the carrot, Trump can focus on what he believes Netanyahu wants – political success, and an end to the prime minister’s legal troubles.

Speaking at the Knesset to mark the ceasefire in early October, Trump called upon Israel’s President Isaac Herzog to pardon Netanyahu in the multiple corruption cases he has faced since 2019.

“Trump can do that,” Mekelberg said. “He can say to Netanyahu, look, I’ll come over. I’ll talk to the Knesset, I can even ask for you to be pardoned, but in return, you follow the script.”

Suggestions that Israel has lost much of its independence in its dealings with the US have appeared to rankle Netanyahu.

‘‘I want to put it very clearly. One week, they say that Israel controls the United States. A week later, they say the United States controls Israel. This is hogwash,” said the prime minister, in response to a question about Israel being beholden to the US.

Irrespective of Netanyahu’s protestations about US control of Israel, much of the evidence contradicts him. In addition to the current US diplomatic blitz, intended to ensure that Netanyahu carries through with the ceasefire, there are other instances of the Trump administration determining Israeli policy.

The ceasefire itself was announced during Netanyahu’s last visit to Washington, seen as a tactic by some observers intended to have the prime minister commit to its terms publicly before returning to Israel.

Similarly, during the same visit, Netanyahu found himself being shepherded into issuing a formal apology to the Qatari Prime Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman bin Jassim Al Thani for the strike on Doha. And critically, during the conclusion of Israel’s 12-day war on Iran in June, it was Trump who ordered Netanyahu to stop a planned Israeli strike after the start of the ceasefire.

For observers such as Pinkas, these actions have been a pointed reminder to Netanyahu and others of the asymmetrical nature of the relationship between Israel and the US, not least under the Trump administration.

“They’re [also] delineating Israel’s freedom of movement,” Pinkas said. “They’re letting Netanyahu and others know that they’re free to go so far without consultation, but that’s it.

“[And] they’re reminding Netanyahu that he’s essentially out of options in the US. The Democrats can’t stand him, public opinion has turned against him, and there are many in the Republican Party, and specifically the MAGA [Make America Great Again] wing, who are asking questions about him. He can no longer play one side against the other. This is it.”

articles.title: Brazil’s President Lula announces he will seek a fourth term in 2026
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Brazilian President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva has announced he will run for re-election in 2026, seeking a fourth nonconsecutive term, despite being 80 years old. Lula, who returned to office in 2023 after 13 years in exile, remains eligible due to Brazil’s two-term limit not applying to non-consecutive terms. His announcement is framed within broader diplomatic activity, including a state visit to Indonesia and a planned meeting with U.S. President Donald Trump in Malaysia, where they are expected to discuss trade tensions stemming from Trump’s 50-percent tariff on Brazil. This tariff backlash has boosted Lula’s popularity, even as half of Brazilian voters disapprove of him. Bolsonaro, who is currently serving a 27-year prison sentence for attempted coup, remains politically influential, potentially shaping opposition dynamics. Although no strong challenger has emerged, analysts suggest that Bolsonaro’s network could mobilize a future opponent. Lula currently leads the polls, signaling strong public support amid ongoing political and international challenges.

Title: Brazil’s President Lula announces he will seek a fourth term in 2026

Brazilian President  Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva  has announced he will run for re-election next year, seeking a fourth nonconsecutive term.

Speaking during a state visit to Indonesia on Thursday, President Lula said he remains energised despite his age.

“I’m turning 80, but you can be sure I have the same energy I had when I was 30. And I’m going to run for a fourth term in Brazil,” Lula told reporters in a joint news conference with Indonesian President Prabowo Subianto.

He then turned to Subianto to deliver a quip: “I’m telling you this because we’re still going to see each other many times.”

Brazil’s constitution allows presidents to serve only two consecutive terms. Lula, who served two terms in 2003-2010, returned to office in 2023 after 13 years out of power and thus remains eligible to run again.

The Brazilian leader is currently on a diplomatic trip across Asia. After his visit to Indonesia, Lula will head to Malaysia to attend the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) summit.

While in Malaysia, Lula is expected to meet on Sunday with United States President Donald Trump, their first in-person encounter following a conciliatory phone call earlier this month, Brazilian media has reported.

The two leaders  have clashed  over the prosecution of former far-right Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro — an ally of Trump — and international trade.

Trump and Lula are expected to discuss the  50-percent trade tariff  that Trump imposed on Brazil in August, in protest against the Bolsonaro prosecution.

Lula had previously said his 2022 presidential bid would be his final campaign, both because of his age and because he believed the country needed political renewal. That election saw him narrowly defeat Bolsonaro in a run-off.

But early in his current term — his third — Lula began hinting that he might run again.

In February 2023, the president said he could seek re-election in 2026, adding that his decision would depend on the country’s political context and his health.

A dominant figure on Brazil’s left, Lula is the country’s longest-serving president since its return to  democracy  40 years ago.

Some Brazilian politicians have expressed concern about Lula’s age and recent health issues. He underwent emergency surgery to treat a brain bleed late last year after a fall in the bathroom. Still, Lula frequently insists he remains healthy and energetic, often sharing workout videos on social media.

Lula currently leads all polls for the 2026 election, though roughly half of voters say they disapprove of him. Trump’s tariffs reenergised the Brazilian leader and pushed his popularity up.

His main political rival, Bolsonaro, has been barred from running for office and was sentenced in September to 27 years in prison for attempting a coup.

While no strong opposition candidate has yet emerged, analysts say a viable contender is likely to depend on Bolsonaro’s backing as he serves his sentence under house arrest.

articles.title: Pakistan launches its first hyperspectral satellite
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Pakistan has successfully launched its first hyperspectral satellite, H1, from China’s Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre on October 19, 2025, through its space agency SUPARCO. This marks a pivotal advancement in Pakistan’s space capabilities and national development, enabling improved monitoring of agriculture, water resources, environmental changes, and disaster risks. The satellite uses hyperspectral imaging to detect subtle material changes on Earth’s surface—offering precision in crop quality assessment and geohazard prediction. The mission is seen as a key milestone in Pakistan’s space program, reflecting its strategic partnership with China and supporting national initiatives such as the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC). The situation underscores the growing strategic competition over semiconductor supply chains in the context of AI development and global technology dominance.

Title: Why has Dutch government taken control of China-owned chipmaker Nexperia?

The Dutch government has intervened to take effective control of technology group Nexperia, which is owned by Chinese group Wingtech Technology.

The decision comes amid a growing rift between China and the West over the development of technology such as computer chips and semiconductors, which are essential components for the manufacture of artificial intelligence (AI) technology.

Here is more about what the Dutch government announced, why and what happens next.

In a statement released on Sunday, the Dutch Ministry of Economic Affairs said it had invoked the “highly exceptional” Goods Availability Act to intervene and take control of Nexperia on September 30.

The Goods Availability Act allows the Netherlands to intervene in privately owned companies in exceptional circumstances, such as if the government perceives a threat to the country’s economic security or if it is necessary to ensure that critical goods remain available.

The move followed an emergency hearing by the Dutch Enterprise Chamber on October 7, which concluded that there may be “valid reasons to doubt sound management at Nexperia under the leadership of former CEO Zhang Xuezheng”, a statement from the company said.

The Dutch Enterprise Chamber is a special division of the Amsterdam Court of Appeal, which hears corporate law cases and other matters that could have major social or financial consequences.

In its statement, the government said the intervention had been carried out “due to serious administrative shortcomings” at Nexperia, which “posed a threat to the continuity and safeguarding on Dutch and European soil of crucial technological knowledge and capabilities”.

It claimed that the intervention would ensure Nexperia’s finished and semi-finished products would remain available in case of an emergency.

The ministry added that “losing these capabilities could pose a risk to Dutch and European economic security.”

Following this intervention, it said, “the company’s regular production process can continue.”

However, it added, “Based on the order, decisions within the company can be blocked or reversed if they are (potentially) harmful to the company’s interests, its future as a Dutch and European company, and/or the preservation of this crucial value chain for Europe.”

The statement said that “involved parties” can appeal the decision in court.

Nexperia is a global semiconductor manufacturer headquartered in Nijmegen, the Netherlands. It emerged as a result of electronics group Philips’ purchase of London-based Mullard Radio Valve Company and Hamburg-based Valvo in the 1920s, ultimately forming Philips’ semiconductor operation. In 2006, Philips spun off its semiconductor division, which became NXP Semiconductors, and this was later sold to a consortium of investors led by Beijing Jianguang Asset Management (JAC Capital). Wingtech acquired Nexperia from that consortium for $3.63bn in 2018.

According to its website, Nexperia employs 12,500 people in Europe, Asia and the United States.

Nexperia’s manufacturing site spans more than 80,000 square metres (861,000dsq feet) and has the capacity to build more than 50 billion components annually. It also has sales offices and research-and-development sites in China.

On Tuesday, Nexperia announced that it had suspended Zhang, founder of Wingtech, as a director and removed him as chief executive officer (CEO). It has appointed Stegan Tilger, chief financial officer (CFO), as interim CEO.

“Due to the same serious managerial shortcomings, the Dutch Ministry of Economic Affairs observed that Nexperia’s operations in Europe were being compromised in an unacceptable manner. This situation raised broader concerns for the Dutch government about the availability of semiconductor products critical to the European industry,” Nexperia’s statement said.

“The combination of Zhang Xuezheng’s behaviour as CEO and (indirect) shareholder, as well as concerns about the semiconductor product availability in the Netherlands and Europe, ultimately led the Dutch government to intervene with an exceptional emergency order on the basis of the Goods Availability Act.”

The statement added that the government’s order has also prohibited Nexperia from relocating company assets, firing existing executives or making important decisions without explicit government approval for one year.

Nexperia said it is confident its daily operations will continue as usual.

On October 9, China  tightened export controls  for critical rare-earth metals, citing national security interests. Foreign companies must now obtain approval from Beijing before they can export the named rare-earth metals or any products that contain them. Exporters must tell the government how the products will be used.

The US is a major consumer of Chinese rare-earth metals, which are critical for its defence industry. Following China’s announcement about new export restrictions, US President Donald Trump responded by  threatening to impose a new 100 percent trade tariff  on China.

Besides being used for the manufacture of smartphones, electric cars and weapons, rare-earth metals are also used in the manufacture of semiconductors, which are essential for the development of artificial intelligence (AI) technology.

The US and its Western allies in Europe have, in recent years, passed regulations restricting China’s access to Western semiconductor technology, fearing that China could reverse-engineer and manufacture the technology, moving ahead in the technological race.

In 2022, former Democratic US President Joe Biden  restricted China’s access  to US semiconductors. The new rules extended restrictions on chipmaking tools being sold to industries which support the semiconductor supply chain. They blocked these industries from accessing US technical expertise, as well as the key components required to build the machines that produce microchips.

The US further tightened these restrictions in October 2023 and, again, in December 2024.

On September 29, 2025, the US Bureau of Industry and Security extended US export control restrictions to all groups which are at least 50 percent-owned by one or more entities on the US Entity List, a list of foreign organisations and companies believed to be participating in, or are at significant risk of participating in, activities that go against US national security or foreign policy interests. These entities are subject to sanctions, export restrictions or licensing requirements. While Nexperia itself is not on the list, Wingtech was added in December 2024.

Then, on October 4, China’s Ministry of Commerce announced export controls preventing Nexperia China and its subcontractors from exporting certain finished components and sub-assemblies made in China.

“Nexperia is actively engaging with the Chinese authorities to obtain an exemption from these restrictions and has deployed all available resources to that end,” the Nexperia statement said.

“While Nexperia has made sufficient preparations to ensure business continuity – and as the BIS rule provides for a 60-day grace period – we are confident that a solution will be found,” Nexperia said in its statement on Tuesday.

Compounding all this, earlier in the year, US President Donald Trump imposed tariffs of 145 percent on Chinese imports to the US. China retaliated with a tariff of 125 percent on US goods. Both countries then reduced their tariffs for 90 days in  May  to allow for trade talks. In August, the two agreed to another 90-day pause, with the most recent round of talks taking place between US and Chinese officials in Spain last month.

But the US has also imposed restrictions on most Chinese cars from being sold in the US. These include high tariffs on Chinese-made electric vehicles.

In addition to its standard 10 percent car import duty, the EU announced last year that it would impose a range of additional tariffs on electric vehicles, from 7.8 percent for Tesla vehicles to 35.3 percent on China’s state-owned SAIC [Shanghai Automotive Industry Corporation] vehicles.

Wingtech released a social media statement saying it “firmly opposes the politicisation of commercial matters”.

In the post, it deemed the Dutch government’s move “an excessive intervention based on geopolitical bias rather than a fact-based risk assessment” that is based on the “unfounded pretext of national security”.

Shares in Wingtech have plummeted by 10 percent on the Shanghai Stock Exchange since the announcement. As a result, Wingtech was forced to explain the situation to the exchange, saying that the Dutch government’s decision “temporarily restricts” its control over Nexperia.

Beijing “consistently opposes the overstretching of national security concepts and discriminatory practices targeting companies from specific countries”, Lin Jian, spokesperson for the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs, said on Monday.

“Relevant countries should genuinely uphold market principles and avoid politicising economic and trade issues.”

The European Union has been closely coordinating with Dutch officials and will now work with the Netherlands to decide what to do next to protect important tech capabilities in Europe, according to European Commission spokesperson Olof Gill.

articles.title: Is your beef linked to Amazon deforestation? A report highlights loopholes
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: A Human Rights Watch investigation reveals that JBS, the world’s largest meat company, is complicit in Amazon deforestation through its untraceable supply chain, particularly in Pará, Brazil, where cattle from illegally deforested and protected areas are moved via a 'laundering' system using group-level animal transit permits (GTAs) that lack individual tracking. The report highlights that JBS cannot guarantee the origin of its beef, as it fails to track its indirect suppliers, and that state agencies like Adepará have authorized cattle transport into protected Indigenous and sustainable zones, such as Cachoeira Seca and Terra Nossa, without environmental oversight. This loophole enables illegal ranching and human rights abuses, especially against Indigenous communities. The article underscores the failure of both JBS and the Brazilian government to fulfill past commitments, with experts urging immediate federal action—such as public access to GTA data and enforceable traceability systems—to hold corporations accountable. The report is especially timely ahead of COP30, where global climate leadership will confront corporate responsibility in agriculture and deforestation.
keyTakeAways: JBS, the world’s largest meat company, is implicated in fueling deforestation in the Brazilian Amazon through its supply chain, particularly in Pará, where cattle from illegally deforested areas are transported via a 'laundering' system.
Human Rights Watch's 86-page report reveals that JBS does not track its indirect cattle suppliers, creating a gap where illegal ranches can operate without being identified or punished.

Cattle are moved through a system of animal transit permits (GTAs), which only record group-level data (number, sex, age), not individual origins—making full traceability impossible and allowing illegal cattle to enter the meat supply chain undetected.

Two protected areas—Cachoeira Seca Indigenous territory and Terra Nossa—have been illegally encroached upon, with state agency Adepará registering ranches and authorizing cattle transport, despite no environmental oversight.
The Brazilian government, including Pará's governor and the Ministry of Agriculture, has introduced traceability mandates, but experts warn these timelines are too slow and enforcement remains weak.
JBS previously committed in 2009 to trace all indirect suppliers by 2011 but failed—demonstrating a pattern of broken promises and inadequate corporate responsibility.

Experts and advocacy groups argue that voluntary corporate pledges are insufficient and demand stronger federal regulations, including public access to GTA data, to enable law enforcement and supply chain accountability.
The report is especially relevant ahead of COP30, where global leaders will discuss climate action, underscoring the need for transparency in agricultural supply chains linked to deforestation.

Title: Is your beef linked to Amazon deforestation? A report highlights loopholes

The world’s largest meat company, JBS, has allegedly fuelled illegal deforestation, land grabs and human rights abuses in the Brazilian Amazon by sourcing cattle from ranches operating inside protected areas, according to a new Human Rights Watch investigation.

On Wednesday, the nonprofit issued an 86-page report focusing on the state of Pará, where the United Nations will hold its annual climate change summit, COP30, next month.

The report highlights a gap in JBS’s supply chain: Human Rights Watch claims the meat company does not track its indirect cattle suppliers.

Investigators found that cattle raised on illegally deforested land were moved through a “laundering” system that concealed their origins before they reached JBS.

That, in turn, means JBS cannot guarantee that its beef or leather products are not contributing to deforestation and related abuses.

Without a better system for tracing livestock, JBS will continue to be “unable to root out illegal cattle ranches”, according to Luciana Téllez, a senior environment researcher at Human Rights Watch.

And what JBS does not know could make it responsible for bankrolling illegal ranches that clear-cut the Amazon, she explained.

“We cannot say with 100-percent certainty that the cattle that JBS purchased from its direct suppliers are the same ones that are coming from illegal cattle ranches, but neither can JBS,” Téllez told Al Jazeera.

“That’s a problem, because they are responsible for what they are procuring.”

Wednesday’s report is part of an ever-growing body of literature delving into the impact agriculture has had on the Amazon rainforest.

The construction of ranches and farmland is considered the single biggest direct cause of deforestation in the world’s tropical regions.

The Amazon rainforest is no exception. In recent years, cattle ranching has emerged as a primary culprit in the levelling of its tangled, biodiverse jungles.

The northern state of Pará is key to the fight against further loss. It has consistently recorded the highest levels of deforestation in the Brazilian Amazon since 2016.

In 2024 alone, 17,195 square kilometres (6,639 sq miles) of forest in the state were degraded, a 421-percent increase over the previous year, according to Human Rights Watch.

The state also reports the second-largest number of land conflicts in Brazil, with illegal ranchers, farmers and criminal groups seeking to invade protected land.

For Indigenous and traditional communities that consider the Amazon home, these invasions have been devastating. Residents have seen their crops destroyed, the forest burned, and their lives displaced.

In some cases, community members have even been threatened, attacked or killed after denouncing the land grabs.

Though federal law prohibits such activity, some land-grabbers have succeeded in fraudulently registering protected rainforest as private properties.

Wednesday’s report documented encroachments in two protected areas: the Cachoeira Seca Indigenous territory and the Terra Nossa sustainable development area.

“The level of violence and intimidation by land grabbers in Terra Nossa is truly frightening, and the absolute impunity they’ve enjoyed for years is astonishing,” Tellez told Al Jazeera.

Human Rights Watch said that Pará’s state animal health agency, Adepará, had registered ranches in both tracts of land. It also authorised the transportation of cattle in and out of the two areas.

According to the report, Adepará claimed that it has not historically been tasked with observing environmental criteria when authorising livestock movements.

But with the state agency’s approval, Human Rights Watch said cattle were raised illegally inside the protected rainforest zones and then transferred out to other ranches.

From there, they could reach major slaughterhouses, including JBS facilities.

Each transfer helped obscure the cattle’s illegal origin, effectively laundering the animals into the meat trade.

Part of the problem, according to Human Rights Watch, is Brazil’s system for tracking livestock.

Brazil does not keep full histories of individual animals. Instead, their movements are documented with “animal transit permits”, known as Guias de Trânsito Animal or GTAs.

Those permits collect information about overall shipments of animals: the number of cattle involved, plus data about the sex and the age of those in the group.

But without an individual record for every cow, calf and bull, it is difficult, if not impossible, to trace their origins.

In an April filing to the United States Securities and Exchange Commission, JBS acknowledged the loopholes in how the GTA system traces cattle.

“As a result, there can be no assurance that available monitoring procedures can ensure that the origin of any head of cattle was in full compliance with applicable laws,” JBS wrote.

The company has promised to require its suppliers to declare their suppliers by 2026. Yet, Human Rights Watch says it remains unclear how such information would be verified or enforced.

“The best solution is for the federal government itself to institute a traceability mechanism for cattle across Brazil,” Tellez said. “The Brazilian government is moving towards that, but it’s moving extremely slowly.”

JBS also made a similar commitment more than a decade and a half ago. In 2009, the company signed the G4 Cattle Agreement with environmental group Greenpeace, pledging to identify all its indirect suppliers by 2011. It failed to meet that deadline.

“It’s unacceptable that companies such as JBS have not fulfilled the promises that they made in the past,” Cristiane Mazzetti, a forest campaign coordinator at Greenpeace Brazil, told Al Jazeera.

“It’s something that now governments need to reflect upon and regulate in a more stringent way, because only believing in voluntary corporate commitments is not going to deliver.”

JBS did not respond to Al Jazeera’s request for comment by publication.

But reform may be on the horizon. In 2023, Pará’s governor introduced a decree requiring all animal movements in the state to be fully traceable by the end of 2026.

At the federal level, the Ministry of Agriculture announced a similar plan in December 2024, mandating that all states implement tracking systems by 2032.

However, Human Rights Watch warns that this timeline is too slow and could allow illegal ranching to persist for years.

Experts and advocacy groups say that Brazil should take immediate steps, including by making GTA data publicly accessible. Such measures would help law enforcement agencies identify fraudulent movements and trace cattle back to illegal ranches.

“Companies struggle with traceability, firstly because they have minimal access to public data on the production chain,” said Lisandro Inakake, an agronomist with the Brazilian environmental nonprofit Imaflora.

He added that the struggle is compounded “because there are no universal market requirements covering all of the companies’ operations”.

While Human Rights Watch has called on JBS to voluntarily start tracing the lifespan of its cattle, Mazzetti, the Greenpeace campaigner, believes more decisive action is necessary if deforestation is to be stopped.

“It’s not time for new promises,” she said. “It’s time to be held accountable for all the impacts that their supply chain generated in the Amazon, in other ecosystems, and also on the climate.”

articles.title: China tightens export controls on rare-earth metals: Why this matters
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: China has expanded its export controls on rare-earth metals, restricting 12 of the 17 known rare-earth elements—including five new ones—and banning exports of specialized refining equipment. The measures, announced in 'Announcement Number 61 of 2025' and effective from December 1, 2025, are framed as national security actions due to concerns over foreign entities using these materials for military applications. The timing—just weeks before a high-level meeting between US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping at the APEC summit in South Korea—suggests a strategic move to strengthen China’s leverage in trade negotiations. The US, which imported $22.8 million in rare-earth products from China in 2023 and relied on 70% of its rare-earth supply from China, is particularly vulnerable. These metals are essential for critical technologies, including defence systems like F-35 jets, submarines, missiles, and AI semiconductors. Analysts from CSIS and the University of Montana interpret the move as a signalling tactic to demonstrate China’s ability to disrupt supply chains, thereby pressuring the US to negotiate on more favorable terms. While emergency medical and disaster relief exports remain exempt, the broader implications include deepening the US’s technological and defence vulnerability amid rising Indo-Pacific tensions.
keyTakeAways: China has tightened export controls on 12 out of 17 rare-earth metals, including five new additions (holmium, erbium, thulium, europium, ytterbium) and seven previously restricted ones (samarium, gadolinium, terbium, dysprosium, lutetium, scandium, yttrium).
The restrictions apply to rare-earth metals with at least 0.1% heavy rare-earth content and to specialized equipment used in refining rare-earth metals.
Foreign companies must obtain special approvals from Beijing to export rare-earth magnets and certain semiconductor materials, and must explain the intended use of the products.
China cites national security interests, citing concerns about foreign entities transferring or processing controlled materials for military or sensitive applications.

The move is seen as a strategic leverage tactic ahead of a Trump-Xi meeting during the APEC summit in South Korea, signaling China's willingness to weaponize its dominant position in the rare-earth supply chain.
The US is the largest importer of Chinese rare-earth metals and products, having imported $22.8 million in 2023, with 70% of its rare-earth imports originating from China between 2020 and 2023.

Rare-earth metals are essential for key technologies such as electric vehicles, lithium-ion batteries, LED TVs, camera lenses, and defence systems including F-35 jets, submarines, missiles, and AI semiconductors.
The restrictions may deepen the US defence and technological capability gap and hinder US efforts to build domestic supply chains amid rising Indo-Pacific tensions.
China has stated that emergency medical supplies, disaster relief, and public health responses will be exempt from the restrictions.
The US has previously restricted China’s access to semiconductors, indicating a reciprocal strategic dynamic in the tech and defence supply chains.

Title: China tightens export controls on rare-earth metals: Why this matters

China tightened export controls for critical rare-earth metals on Thursday.

The new restrictions, announced by the Ministry of Commerce, come in advance of an expected meeting between United States President Donald Trump and his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping, later this month.

The world’s two largest economies have been locked in trade negotiations aimed at calming tensions, after their tit-for-tat tariffs against each other earlier this year, before agreeing to pull back some of those duties.

Rare-earth metals are one of China’s major levers of influence with the US.

In “announcement number 61 of 2025”, China said it was increasing export controls for five rare-earth metals in addition to the  seven it announced in April this year .

The five metals added to the list are holmium, erbium, thulium, europium and ytterbium.

The seven minerals China placed export restrictions on earlier this year are samarium, gadolinium, terbium, dysprosium, lutetium, scandium and yttrium.

There are 17 rare-earth metals in total – the 15 lanthanides (metallic elements) on the periodic table, as well as scandium and yttrium. China now has export restrictions on 12 of them.

Additionally, China also placed restrictions on the export of specialist technological equipment used to refine rare-earth metals on Thursday. Most of these restrictions will come into effect on December 1.

The announcement means that foreign companies will need to obtain special approvals from Beijing if they wish to export rare-earth magnets and certain semiconductor materials that have at least 0.1 percent heavy rare-earth metals from China.

To obtain the licence, foreign companies must explain the intended use of the product they wish to make using Chinese rare-earth metals.

China cited national security interests as the reason for these new restrictions.

“Rare-earth-related items have dual-use properties for both civilian and military applications. Implementing export controls on them is an international practice,” a Chinese Commerce Ministry spokesperson told reporters.

The spokesperson added that “certain” foreign organisations and individuals have been directly transferring – or processing and then transferring – controlled rare-earth materials originating from China to “relevant organisations and individuals directly or indirectly for military and other sensitive applications”.

“This has caused significant damage or posed potential threats to China’s national security and interests, adversely affected international peace and stability, and hindered global non-proliferation efforts.”

Rare-earth metals are essential for the production of technological equipment such as electric cars, lithium-ion batteries, LED televisions and camera lenses.

The metals are crucial for the US defence industry. According to the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS) think tank, rare earths are used to manufacture components of F-35 fighter jets, Virginia and Columbia-class submarines, Tomahawk missiles, radar systems, Predator unmanned aerial vehicles and the Joint Direct Attack Munition series of smart bombs.

Additionally, rare earths are used to create semiconductors, which are used in artificial intelligence (AI) technology.

This is a strategic move on the part of China, analysts say.

China is the largest producer of these rare-earth metals. It mines at least 60 percent and processes about 90 percent of the world’s rare-earth metals, CSIS reported in 2024.

The new restrictions have been announced just three weeks before Trump visits South Korea to attend the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) summit in late October.

During his visit, Trump is expected to meet Xi. The leaders last met in person in 2019.

Earlier this year, Trump imposed tariffs of 145 percent on Chinese imports to the US. China retaliated with 125 percent tariffs. After reducing their tariffs to 30 percent and 10 percent, respectively, in May, the two sides struck a truce in August, agreeing on a 90-day pause to allow time for trade talks. That pause has since been renewed twice as talks continue – most recently between US and Chinese officials in Spain last month.

China’s new restrictions on rare-earth metals, which Trump is known to want badly, give it more leverage for these talks.

Gracelin Baskaran, director of the CSIS Critical Minerals Security Program, explained that the US defence industry is facing significant challenges caused by its limited production ability to meet rising defence technology needs. By restricting exports, China may be able to accelerate the expansion of its military strength at a faster pace than the US.

“The new restrictions will only deepen these vulnerabilities, further widening the capability gap,” Baskaran said.

“The move both strengthens Beijing’s leverage in upcoming talks while also undercutting US efforts to bolster its industrial base at a time where Indo-Pacific tension is climbing,” she said.

“Most [restrictions] don’t go into effect until December 1, 2025, leaving close to 2.5 months for these negotiations.”

The Chinese Commerce Ministry spokesperson told reporters on Thursday: “China is willing to strengthen communication and cooperation through bilateral and multilateral export control dialogue mechanisms, promote compliant trade, and ensure the security and stability of global industrial and supply chains.”

Kristin Vekasi, the Mansfield chair of Japan and Indo-Pacific Affairs at the University of Montana, said Beijing’s latest moves are about leverage. She said this is a part of “pre-meeting choreography” before Trump’s meeting with Xi during the APEC summit in South Korea.

“China hasn’t yet pulled the trigger on export restrictions, but it’s reminding Washington that it could. This move signals that Beijing is willing to weaponise its dominant position in the rare earths supply chain, especially as both governments prepare for a potential Trump-Xi meeting at APEC. It’s a classic signalling manoeuvre designed to strengthen China’s negotiating hand.”

The US will be especially hit hard. In 2023, it was the largest importer of Chinese rare-earth minerals and products, importing $22.8m worth of products from China, according to the Observatory of Economic Complexity (OEC). In total, China exported $117m in rare-earth metals and products that year.

The US sourced 70 percent of its rare-earth compounds and metals imports from China between 2020 and 2023, according to a US Geological Survey report.

“On the defence side, we’re talking about inputs for fighter jets, missile guidance systems, and more. On the civilian side, everything from smartphones and medical imaging equipment to electric vehicles depends on rare earth magnets. In other words, this isn’t just about defence but touches the everyday technologies that enable our modern life,” Vekasi said.

Hong Kong ($12.1m), Russia ($12.2m) and Japan ($9.42m) also import significant amounts.

The US restricted China’s access to its semiconductors in 2022 under the administration of Democratic former President Joe Biden. Some US lawmakers have pushed for greater restrictions, warning that China could reverse-engineer or independently develop advanced semiconductor technologies, overtaking the US in the industry and securing a military advantage.

“China’s move shows it can make life very difficult for US manufacturers – but doing so would also hurt its own economy, since many of these supply chains run both ways. It’s a reminder that the US-China economic relationship isn’t a clean decoupling story; the two markets are still very much intertwined,” Vekasi from the University of Montana said.

Yes.

The Commerce Ministry spokesperson said exports pertaining to emergency medical needs, in response to public health emergencies or for disaster relief, will be exempt from the restrictions.

articles.title: UN pushes for worldwide disaster alerts as extreme weather ‘spirals’
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The World Meteorological Organization (WMO), a UN agency, is urging global action to close critical gaps in early-warning systems for extreme weather, noting that nearly half of all countries lack them—especially in developing nations. With over 2 million deaths from weather and climate disasters in the past 50 years, and deaths six times higher in countries without warnings, the WMO stresses that timely alerts are essential for saving lives and protecting infrastructure. While progress has been made in expanding early-warning systems globally (from 52 to 108 countries), half still have only basic capacity. The article highlights real-world examples, such as the successful evacuation of the Swiss village of Blatten in May 2025 after a glacier collapse was predicted, and rising disasters in Pakistan, Nigeria, South Korea, and southern Europe in 2025. The WMO emphasizes that early warning systems are not just about alerts but about enabling early action, with a focus on empowering vulnerable communities and fragile regions.
keyTakeAways: Nearly half of all countries lack effective early-warning systems for extreme weather, increasing vulnerability—especially in developing nations.
Disaster-related deaths are six times higher in countries without early-warning systems, with 90% of deaths in the past 50 years occurring in developing countries.
Over 2 million people have died from weather, water, and climate-related hazards in the past 50 years.
While 108 countries now use some form of multi-hazard early warning systems (up from 52), half still have only basic capacity and 16% have less than basic capacity.
The situation is most dire in fragile, conflict-affected regions.
Progress is being seen in Africa, with more countries launching functioning alert websites and standardized warnings.
The WMO emphasizes that early warning leads to early action and aims to empower communities rather than just issue alerts.
A glacier collapse in Switzerland in May 2025 was predicted through monitoring, leading to the evacuation of the village of Blatten, demonstrating the life-saving potential of early warning systems.
